text: today on the caucus Cheryl gay stolberg
and Paul volpe discuss Michelle
Bachmann's evangelical beliefs and its
role in her career and in her
presidential campaign so Cheryl you've
been doing a lot of reporting on Michele
Bachmann how she rose through Minnesota
political circles by focusing a lot on
social issues but on the campaign trail
right now she's runs for president we're
not seeing a lot of that that's exactly
right you know here in Washington we
know Michele Bachmann as a tea party
star and a fiscal conservative but back
home in Minnesota where she was elected
to the state Senate in 2000 she really
built her career on social issues and in
particular her opposition to same-sex
marriage she pushed really hard to bring
that issue to the fore and it was her
banner issue there you talked to a lot
of people or former colleagues in the
state Senate and you know political
observers how was michelle bachman
viewed by people back in Minnesota um i
would say people in Minnesota either
love her or hate her she's very divisive
but I will say this I think almost
everybody in Minnesota looks at her with
a kind of admiration either grudging or
genuine at her incredible ability to
seize on an issue use it to rally her
base to speak publicly about it she's
very dynamic and to sort of take that
issue and basically circumvent the party
establishment and make it her own which
is exactly what we've seen her don't do
here in Washington she's kind of gone
around the establishment and she's
become the star you talk about in your
story about how Michele Bachmann has
very strong views about homosexuality
she has referred to it as being in
bondage her husband you know there are
some reports that his counseling
Christian counseling is does some what
they would call repert of therapy or
some people call gay to straight therapy
what did you find in your reporting on
that first of all Michele Bachmann and
her husband are very like-minded so like
Michele Bachmann Marcus Bachmann has
made very strong arguments in public on
Christian radio shows etc that children
are at risk when parents and educators
tolerate homosexuality the questions
that have been swirling
Marcus Bachmann are about whether or not
he practices so-called reparative
therapy this is extremely controversial
and he himself has said that he would
his clinic would offer such counseling
if a client asked for it now that is a
position that puts him at odds with most
mainstream medical associations who view
reparative therapy as harmful and
ineffective my bottom line conclusion is
that the clinic most likely does offer
this therapy as dr. Bachman himself has
said to clients who asked for it but my
sense is it's probably not the bulk of
their business how do you think that
this will play with with voters as
Michele Bachmann you know as the
presidential campaign gets going I think
we're already seeing how it's going to
play with Republican primary voters
especially conservatives who really like
Michelle Bachmann she's created a lot of
excitement on the campaign trail so I
think it's great for her right now the
question is how would it play in a
general election were should it become
the nominee or perhaps a vice
presidential nominee as some think how
divisive will she be because just as
Minnesotans either love her or hate her
I suspect that in a general election
campaign Americans would either love her
or hate her so I guess the question at
the end of the day is which side loves
or hates more
you
